doc.title: Furukawa Electric (5801)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Raise PO See upside from AI server-related demandRaise PO See upside from AI server-related demand_2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 11,500 JPY | Price: 8,870 JPY

We raise our price objective (PO) for Furukawa Electric to reflect upward revisions to our RP forecasts due to earnings improvement at Asia Vital Components. Our PO is based on a P/E of 16.5x (was 16x) and our FY3/27 estimate, reflecting its robust growth potential. Our Buy rating rests on expectations for earnings to beat the consensus, driven by growth in Al server-related electronic materials, optical cables and optical components.

We leave our FY3/26 RP forecast unchanged at 57.0bn, but raise our estimate for FY3/27 from 72.0bn to 74.0bn (consensus: 66.2bn). We forecast 2Q RP at 12.2bn, below the consensus of 14.6bn. As evident in 1Q results, we anticipate an increase in personnel costs in the communication solutions business in preparation for future expansion of production. We expect full- year guidance to be raised for RP and net profit (NP) due to improvement in equity- method income. This should act as a positive catalyst for the share price.

Amphenol's \(10.5bn acquisition of CommScope's connectivity & cable solutions (CCS) business (see our 4 August report on Amphenol) should give a boost to Furukawa Electric's optical fiber & cable products business. We think that CommScope is probably a major customer of Furukawa Electric, and with Amphenol likely to try and expand this newly acquired business, this could well lead to higher shipments of optical fiber at Furukawa Electric. In addition, we believe the acquisition price sheds light on the high valuation assigned to optical fiber- related businesses.

Furukawa Electric, one of the three major wire/cable companies, has diversified into various product categories, and its business now encompasses info- communications such as optical fiber/parts, auto parts such as wire harnesses, electronic materials such as electrolytic copper foil, semiconductor tape and HDD blanks, rolled copper products, rolled aluminum products, and power cables.
Our Buy thesis is premised on our outlook for earnings to beat the consensus on growth for Al server- related electronic materials, optical cable, optical components, power cable, and other products.

We forecast 2Q RP at 12.2bn, below the consensus for 14.6bn from 3Q, we anticipate the launch of products related to data centers oallable ribbon cables and pre- terminated cables), and 2Q will likely have a rise in personncy costs similar to 1Q. In 1Q, costs rose due to increased hiring in preparation for the launch of pre- terminated cables for data centers in North America. In 2Q, North American tariffs on wire harnesses may have a temporary negative impact. However, the company intends to pass on these tariff costs to customers.

We expect operating profit (OP) guidance to remain unchanged at the time 2Q results are released, while RP and NP guidance may be raised. Our expectation for strength in RP reflects an improving profit outlook at equity- method affiliate Asia Vital Components. We view this as a positive share price catalyst.

Furukawa Electric has a broad lineup of data center- related products and is actively ramping up production, which should be a tailwind. In the communication solutions business, such products include rollable ribbon cables, pre- terminated cables, MT ferrules/optical connectors, DFB chips and ITLAs. In the functional products business, data center products include HBM tapes, aluminum blanks for HDDs, thermal products and copper foil. Equity- method affiliate Asia Vital Components also stands to benefit significantly.

In these data center- related products, Furukawa Electric generally has the secondlargest or smaller share of their respective markets, and each individual product does not constitute a large- scale business. As a result, they are more sensitive to fluctuations in industrywide demand. Due to scattered investments, these products at Furukawa Electric tend to lag behind the industry leaders. We view this as a medium/long- term risk to the company's competitiveness.

Furukawa Electric has a wide range of product lines and a diversified portfolio. At the same time, the company is selling shares in non- core listed subsidiaries, such as Furukawa Battery and UACJ, to streamline its business portfolio. It is also investing in core businesses, including the acquisition of shares in Hakusan and Fujitsu Optical Components. We have a positive view of these developments.

Sales at Asia Vital Components, major Taiwanese copper- clad laminate makers such as Elite Material, and Taiwanese copper foil producers such as Co Tech Development (monthly) Export value and volume of Japanese optical connectors and cables (monthly) Production statistics for Japanese laser diodes (monthly) Cable shipment data in Japan (monthly) Vehicle production volumes at Toyota Motor and other Japanese automakers (monthly)

Leave our OP forecasts largely unchanged, as upward revisions to our outlook for automotive components and batteries are offset by downward revisions for functional products and communication solutions; however, raise our RP forecasts due to improving equity- method income from Asia Vital Components
Source: Company, BofA Global Research estimates, IFIS

Exhibit 2: Furukawa Electric (5801): Earnings estimates by segment Raise our outlook for automotive components and batteries, but revise down our outlook for functional products and communication solutions
Source: Company, BofA Global Research estimates

Source: BofA Global Research

Source: BofA Global Research

The main businesses are communications solutions (optical fiber/cable in North America), automotive products (wire harnesses), and functional products (electronic materials). Furukawa Electric is a conglomerate. Equity- method income has a considerable impact. Major equity- method affiliates include Taiwan's Asia Vital Components (3017 TT, 15.5%).

Profits diverge across segments: Functional Products 14.0bn, Electronics Component Materials 4.9bn, Automotive Products and Batteries 27.4bn, Energy Infrastructure 8.9bn, and Communications Solutions - 4.3bn
Source: Company, BofA Global Research

High sales weighting for Automotive Products and Batteries at \(33\%\) of total, followed Electronics Component Materials at \(27\%\) , Communications Solutions at \(14\%\) , Functional Products at \(12\%\) , Energy Infrastructure at \(11\%\) , with \(3\%\) for Service and Developments, etc.
Source: Company, BofA Global Research
It has three subsegments: optical fiber & cable products; Fitel- branded products; and broadband solutions.

Key products and customers: Products include optical fiber, optical cables, mechanically Transferable (MT) ferrules, optical connectors and optical connection products. Telecommunications infrastructure and network applications are the main sources of demand.
Mainly comprises the consolidated subsidiary, OFS.

North America accounts for just over \(70\%\) of sales. Latin America, Europe, Japan, and Asia each account for c.5- 10% of sales. High value- added rollable ribbon cables account for over \(30\%\) of total sales.

Its main customers are Tier 2 and 3 telcos (such as dark fiber providers), OTTs (Over the Top; service providers), and telecommunications construction companies. Furukawa Electric signed an eight- year long- term contract with the US firm CommScope in 2018, and we assume CommScope as a major customer. (Contract ended in 2024)
On 4 August 2025, Amphenol announced the acquisition of CommScope's CCS business for \(10.5bn\) . This will result in Amphenol becoming a major customer of Furukawa Electric.
- Amid strong data center demand, the industry is facing a shortage of high-quality optical fiber, and the company is likely to benefit from its capacity to supply this externally.
- Capacity: Double rollable-ribbon cable capacity in FY3/26 from FY3/24.

- Pre-connectorized cable: The company is establishing production of pre-connectorized cable with a rollable ribbon cable attached to a MT connector. It expects to start shipping soon after one hyperscaler completes its evaluation (as of May 2025).
- In Jan-Mar 2024, OFS's optical fiber cables were officially recognized as being compliant with BEAD (Broadband Equity Access and Deployment) program standards. Corning is also BEAD-compliant.

- At a briefing in June 2024, the company said that it expected BEAD program demand to gradually materialize from 2H FY3/25. It forecasts growth in earnest from FY3/26 with a peak in 2026-27. The five-year program is expected to continue until around 2030. At the August 2024 results briefing, Furukawa Electric said that it now expects the BEAD program demand to emerge later than its original forecast of 2H FY3/25.

- Capacity: Increase in FY3/26 by 5x or more vs. FY3/24- On 30 January, 2025, Furukawa Electric acquired 67% of Hakusan's shares for ¥3,603mn- Hakusan has the second-largest market share in the world for multi-core optical MT ferrules (Fujikura ranks first).- Hakusan posted FY10/24 parent sales of ¥4,785mn OP of ¥1,972mn and NP of ¥1,341mn- Acquisitits customers include Senko Advance, Nakayo and Hakusan Shoji.
Optical fiber is one of Furukawa Electric's major products
Source: Company website
Core products: Mainly optical devices. Integrated tunable laser assembly (ITLA), tunable laser modules, laser excitation modules, and industrial fiber lasers.
ITLA accounts for a large portion of sales.
DFB (Distributed Feedback Laser)

Accounts for \(10 - 20\%\) of sales in FY3/25 Many optical component customers are overseas, including in North America and China. Capacity: Increase in FY3/26 by 5x or more versus FY3/24. Completed \(50\%\) of capacity expansion in FY3/25. Competitors: Mitsubishi Electric, Sumitomo Electric Industries, etc. Increasing production of DFB chips will likely greatly contribute to the realization of the IOWN (Innovative Optical and Wireless Network).
Furukawa Fitel Optical Components (FFOC)

Furukawa Electric announced on 12 December 2024 the acquisition of \(100\%\) stake in Fujitsu Optical Components. It consolidated it on 1 April, 2025. The acquisition price was \(4,423\mathrm{mn}\) FFOC manufactures and sells laser diode modules, splitters, transceivers, and other products Telecom sector is main source of demand. NP was \(461\mathrm{mn}\) in FY3/25.

- It reported FY3/24 sales of ¥13,681mn, operating loss of ¥10,275mn, and net loss of ¥10,627mn.- It had an operating loss of ¥176mn in FY3/23 and OP of ¥3,399 in FY3/22.- FFOC's lithium niobate modulators should contribute greatly to electro-optic integration.
- Core products: FTTH (Fiber-To-The-Home) systems, wireless systems, network routers, and radio base stations in dead zones.- Customers: Cable TV operators, telecom carriers, and railway
It comprises two subsegments: power cables and industrial cables.
- Core products: Ultra-high-voltage/high-voltage underground lines, submarine cables (cables, parts, and laying work), and water distribution piping (including laying work).
- Key bases: Japan (Chiba plant) and China.
- The company is investing a total of ¥15bn over eight years (FY3/19-26) at its Chiba plant.- It is actively investing in renewable energy submarine cable-related equipment.
- Customers: Electric power companies, renewable energy SPCs (Specific Purpose Company) and EPCs (Engineering, Procurement, Construction), and local governments.
- Core products: Industrial cables, overhead transmission components, power distribution components.

- The company is expanding sales of RAKU-RAKU aluminum conductor cable as a strategic product. It targets FY3/26 sales of ¥2.5bn.  
- Sales of the product are growing in the renewable energy market for use in solar power generation equipment due to its ease of installation and theft-deterring features.
- Customers: Construction companies, electric power companies, railway operators, etc.
This is a strategic product.
Source: Company website
It consists of two subsegments: automotive products and batteries.
Core products and customers: Automotive wire harnesses. Its main customers are Japanese automakers.

- FY3/24 sales broke down as follows: wire harnesses 75.1%, SRC (steering roll connectors) 8.2%, BSS (lead-acid battery state sensors) 3.0%, radars 3.8%, high voltage products 1.0%, other 11.7%.- FY3/25 regional breakdown: domestic auto industry nearly 50%, North American auto industry 30%, China, Southeast Asia, and India 20%.  
- In China, the company ships not only to Japanese automakers, but also to local Chinese automakers.
Key bases: Mexico, the Philippines, and Vietnam.
Large facilities in Southeast Asia, a small facility in Mexico.
The business comprises a listed subsidiary, Furukawa Battery (6937 JP; 58.1% stake), which manufactures and sells lead batteries.

From mid- December 2025 Furukawa Electric plans to sell Furukawa Battery to Sustainable Battery Holdings (SBH) in or after July 2025. The transfer price is ¥18.669bn and Furukawa Electric expects to record an extraordinary profit of just under ¥10bn.
One of Furukawa Electric's major products.
Source: Company website
Furukawa Electric is scheduled to sell Furukawa Battery from December 2025.
Source: Company website
It consists of two subsegments: electric conductor (coil wire) and copper products.
The company owns a \(42.4\%\) stake in PT. Tembaga Mulia Semanan, a listed subsidiary in Indonesia.
Core products: Copper and aluminum wires (for wire harnesses), oxygen- free copper wires, and fine wires.
Customers: Manufacturers of coil wires, motors, and electronic components.
Core products: Wrought copper and sheets (semiconductor lead frames, terminals for automobiles and mobile phones) and copper strips.
Customers: Semiconductor component, terminal, and electric cable makers.
Benefit from stronger power cable demand
Source: Company webpage
It comprises four subsegments: AT & functional plastics, thermal management solutions & products, memory disks, and copper foil.
Exhibit 13: Wrought copper and sheets Used for semiconductor lead frame
Source: Company webpage
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Core products: Tape for semiconductor processes (back- grinding tape, dicing tape, dicing die attach film) and functional cables (cable protection pipes, insulation materials).
Back- grinding tape is a protective tape that is used during the backgrinding process to polish and thin the non- circuit- forming surface of semiconductor wafers after front- end wafer processing.
Dicing tape is a tape used to secure wafers to prevent chips from scattering when semiconductor wafers are cut into chips after frontend wafer processing. Thermal management solution & products.
Dicing die attach film (DDF) is a film that combines DC tape and die attach film

There are two types of DDF: one uses Resonac's die attach film and Furukawa Electric's DC tape, and the other utilizes the die attach film and DC tape made by Furukawa Electric. The former, which combines Resonac and Furukawa Electric products, is mainly used for NAND (Not and) Flash memory and has the top DDF market share. The latter, which uses products made in- house, has a low market share.
Transparent tape for high bandwidth memory (HBM) This high- transparency tape enables wafer singulation via laser irradiation.
Customers: electronics manufacturers (Taiwan is the biggest customer), Construction company, and HVAC piping manufacturer
New products for advanced processes are growing. Supply semiconductor production tape for new processes in highbandwidth memory (HBM) production.

Competition and market share: Market shares for back- grinding tape include \(38\%\) at Mitsui Chemicals, \(21\%\) at Lintec, \(19\%\) at Furukawa Electric, and \(18\%\) at Nitto Denko. Market shares for dicing tape include \(29\%\) at Lintec, \(22\%\) at Nitto Denko, \(15\%\) at Furukawa Electric, \(10\%\) at Denka, and \(10\%\) at Sumitomo Bakelite.
Locations: The company operates with three locations, the Hiratsuka Plant, Mie First plant, and Mie Second plant (started operation in April 2025).
Capacity expansion: Built second plant at Mie Works at cost of ¥7bn. Mass production started in April 2025.
In functional resins, Furukawa is seeking growth in next- generation communication device housings (radomes) using the low- dielectric material "Smart Cellular Board".
Core products: Heat sinks and heat pipes, vapor chambers
Customers: Data centers at \(80\%\) , railways at \(20\%\) , and solar power generation. 3D vapor chambers are used in generative AI servers, and Furukawa is benefiting from this demand.

- In FY3/25-26, we expect air-cooling applications will account for nearly 100% and water-cooling applications for almost zero. We expect shipments for water-cooling applications will begin in 2H FY3/27.  
- Equity-method affiliate Products made by Asia Vital Components and Furukawa Electric both compliment and compete with each other.  
- 3D vapor chambers work with the air cooling method. The company has also decided to enter the water cooling method and immersion method areas.  
- Competitors in the water cooling and immersion methods differ from that in the air cooling method.
- Location: Hiratsuka Works, Philippines (Laguna Industrial Park)

- Expansion: On 24 July 2024, Furukawa Electric unveiled that it would build new plants at the Hiratsuka Works and the Laguna Industrial Park to make water-cooled modules for data centers with a view to start mass production in FY3/27.

- Plans call for water-cooled module sales to reach ¥6bn in FY3/27 and ¥25bn in FY3/28.  
- Water-cooled modules are structurally more complex than air-cooled modules and have greater added value.  
- Immersion module sales volume is forecast to increase gradually from FY3/25.
- Main products: Aluminum blanks for HDDs (Hard disk drives).
- Manufacturing base: Japan.
- Capacity: Over 30mn blanks per month
- Customers: Hard-disk media makers (Seagate, Western Digital, Resonac).
- Competitors: Kobe Steel
- Mainstay products: Copper foils (for circuits and lithium-ion batteries).

- Production sites: Imaichi Plant in Japan (circuit foil and battery foil, 300 tons/month), Furukawa Circuit Foil Taiwan (circuit foil, slightly over 1,100 tons/month) and Furukawa Electric Copper Foil Taiwan (battery foil, 500 tons/month).

- Capacity is based on an April 2022 article in the Electronic Device Industry News.  
- Due to a fire in June 2019, Furukawa Electric Copper Foil Taiwan is operating at c.80% of full capacity.
- Customers: Circuit board makers (70% of overall sales) and lithium-ion battery makers (30%; split equally between consumer and automotive applications).
- In FY3/24, copper foil for high-frequency circuit boards used in AI servers, etc. It accounted for 40% in FY3/25. The company expects that to rise to 50% in FY3/26.
- At the June 2025 briefing, management said it had begun mass production and sales up to the hyper very low profile (HVLP) 4 category and is now developing the next-generation HVLP 5 category.
- Competitors: Mitsui Mining & Smelting, Co-tech Development etc.
Furukawa manufactures back- grinding tape, dicing tape, dicing die attach film.
Source: Company webpage
Rapid growth thanks to strong AI sever demand
Source: Company webpage
Exhibit 16: Aluminum blank material for hard disk drives Furukawa has high market share
Source: Company webpage
Copper foils demand grows thanks to strong AI sever demand
Source: Company webpage
- Asia Vital Components (3017 TT, 15.5%): Taiwanese thermal products company.
- Reference report: Asia Vital Components (20 September)
- Each ¥1 depreciation against the dollar boosts annual OP by ¥300-350mn, all else equal.
Dividend payout ratio: The basic policy is to maintain stable and sustained shareholder returns. Management targets a dividend payout ratio of \(30\%\) .
Exhibit 18: Furukawa Electric (5801): Shareholder return value (Bn JPY) Management targets a dividend payout ratio of \(30\%\)
Source: Company, BofA Global Research estimates
OP above \(\yen 58\) bn.
Includes \(\yen 4.2\) bn impact of removing Totoku from consolidation. Expect it also includes \(\yen 4\) bn impact of removing Furukawa Battery from consolidation.
Sales above \(\yen 1.1\) tn.
NP above \(\yen 37\) bn.
Net D/E ratio below 0.8.
Equity ratio above \(35\%\)
Dividend payout ratio target \(30\%\)
Furukawa Electric (5801): Briefing: Poised to benefit further from growth of data center market 21 May 2025
Furukawa Electric (5801): Briefing: Smooth progress on major optical component/rollable ribbon capacity growth 12 February 2025
Furukawa Electric (5801): Briefing: Communications solutions taking longer to recover than expected 06 August 2024

Our price objective (PO) for Furukawa Electric is 11,500, based on a P/E of 16.5x our FY3/27 EPS estimate. We use nearly the highest P/E of the range (9- 17.5x) during the previous earnings recovery in 2016- 17.

Upside risks to our PO are (1) a sharp recovery in US telecom investment and (2) rapid yen depreciation (each 1 depreciation vs USD lifts annual OP by 300- 350mn). Downside risks are (1) stiffer competition and market share loss in thermal management solutions and products, (2) sharp decline in Al server- related investment, and (3) rapid yen appreciation.
Japan-Cyclical Materials Coverage Cluster

Qmethod is the set of BofA Global Research standard measures that serve to maintain global consistency under three broad headings: Business Performance, Quality of Earnings, and validations. The key features of iQmethod are: A consistently structured, detailed, and transparent methodology. Guidelines to maximize the effectiveness of the comparative valuation process, and to identify some common pitfalls. Qatobase is our real-time global research database that is sourced directly from our equity analysts' earnings models and includes forecasted as well as historical data for income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements for companies covered by BofA Global Research.
Profile, Qmethod are service marks of Bank of America Corporation. Qatobase is a registered service mark of Bank of America Corporation.

Any information relating to the tax status of financial instruments discussed herein is not intended to provide tax advice or to be used by anyone to provide tax advice. Investors are urged to seek tax advice based on their particular circumstances from an independent tax professional.

You should therefore assume that BofA Securities will not update any fact, circumstance or opinion contained herein.

Subject to the quiet period applicable under laws of the various jurisdictions in which we distribute research reports and other legal and BofA Securities policy- related restrictions on the publication of research reports, fundamental equity reports are produced on a regular basis as necessary to keep the investment recommendation current.
